message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic Event-Triggered Distributed Coordination Control and its Applications: A Survey of Trends and Techniques
Paper Abstract: Distributed coordination control is the current trend in networked systems and finds prosperous applications across a variety of fields, such as smart grids and intelligent transportation systems. One fundamental issue in coordinating and controlling a large group of distributed and networked agents is the influence of intermittent interagent interactions caused by constrained communication resources. Event-triggered communication scheduling stands out as a promising enabler to strike a balance between the desired control performance and the satisfactory resource efficiency. What distinguishes dynamic event-triggered scheduling from traditional static event-triggered scheduling is that the triggering mechanism can be dynamically adjusted over time in accordance with both available system information and additional dynamic variables. This article provides an up-to-date overview of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control. The motivation of dynamic event-triggered scheduling is first introduced in the context of distributed coordination control. Then some techniques of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control are discussed in detail. Implementation and design issues are well addressed. Furthermore, this article exemplifies two applications of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control in the fields of microgrids and automated vehicles. Several challenges are suggested to direct the future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Now let me identify all the key entities explicitly mentioned in the title and abstract:

**From Title:**
1. "Dynamic Event-Triggered" → **Event-triggered control** (method/concept)
2. "Distributed Coordination Control" → **Distributed control** (method/concept)

**From Abstract:**
3. "networked systems" → **Network (concept)**
4. "smart grids" → **Smart grid** (application/concept)
5. "intelligent transportation systems" → **Intelligent transportation** (application/concept)
6. "distributed and networked agents" → **Multi-agent system** (concept)
7. "constrained communication resources" → **Network communication** (task/constraint)
8. "Event-triggered communication scheduling" → **Event-triggered control** (method)

## Intelligent Transportation System (ITS)

An intelligent transportation system (ITS) is an advanced application that aims to provide services relating to different modes of transport and traffic management and enable users to be better informed and make safer, more coordinated, and 'smarter' use of transport networks.

### Key Technologies and Applications

Intelligent transport systems incorporate a wide range of technologies, from basic management systems such as car navigation, traffic signal control, and variable-message signs, to more advanced, interconnected applications.

Some major components include:

- **Data Collection and Monitoring**: A major application is providing real-time information to passengers, such as predicting the arrival time of public transport by processing data collected from transit vehicles with telematics and GPS tracking units.

- **Fleet Management**: Intelligent fleet management systems leverage telematics to optimize routes, improve fuel efficiency, and enhance the safety of logistics and public transport fleets.

- **Cooperative Systems**: Data is shared through vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communication, allowing for real-time hazard warnings and coordinated traffic flow, enhancing safety and efficiency beyond the capabilities of stand-alone systems.

### Advanced Technologies

Embedded system platforms allow for more sophisticated software applications to be implemented, including model-based process control, artificial intelligence, and ubiquitous computing, with artificial intelligence being perhaps the most important of these for intelligent transportation systems.

Based on the search results, I found some relevant information about event-triggered systems. Here are the key findings:

## Event-Triggered Control

Event-triggered systems are a research area that focuses on analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems. A prominent researcher in this field is Maurice Heemels, a professor at Eindhoven University of Technology, who was named Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

In the context of computing more broadly, event-triggered approaches contrast with time-triggered systems. A time-triggered system is a computer system that executes one or more sets of tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule, whereas event-triggered control operates based on the occurrence of specific events rather than predetermined schedules.

The search results suggest that event-triggered control is a specialized area within control systems and real-time computing, though the results focused more on related concepts like time-triggered architecture and event-driven programming. For more detailed technical information about event-triggered control methodologies, you may want to consult academic publications or specialized control systems literature.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about microgrids:

## Definition

A microgrid is a local electrical grid with defined electrical boundaries, acting as a single and controllable entity.(no content)It is able to operate in grid-connected and off-grid modes.

## How They Work

A microgrid is a localized grouping of electricity generation, energy storage, and loads that normally operates connected to a traditional centralized grid (macrogrid).(no content)This single point of common coupling with the macrogrid can be disconnected. The microgrid can then function autonomously.

## Key Features

Microgrid generation resources can include stationary batteries, fuel cells, solar, wind, or other energy sources.(no content)Microgrids can disconnect from the centralized grid and operate autonomously, strengthen grid resilience, and help mitigate grid disturbances.

## Applications

A stand-alone microgrid has its own sources of electricity, supplemented with an energy storage system. They are used where power transmission and distribution from a major centralized energy source is too far and costly to operate. Additionally, they offer an option for rural electrification in remote areas and on smaller geographical islands.

## Benefits

The multiple dispersed generation sources and ability to isolate the microgrid from a larger network would provide highly reliable electric power.

## Definition

A microgrid is a local electrical grid with defined electrical boundaries, acting as a single and controllable entity.(no content)It is able to operate in grid-connected and off-grid modes.

## How They Work

A microgrid is a localized grouping of electricity generation, energy storage, and loads that normally operates connected to a traditional centralized grid (macrogrid).(no content)This single point of common coupling with the macrogrid can be disconnected. The microgrid can then function autonomously.

## Key Features

Microgrid generation resources can include stationary batteries, fuel cells, solar, wind, or other energy sources.(no content)Microgrids can disconnect from the centralized grid and operate autonomously, strengthen grid resilience, and help mitigate grid disturbances.

## Applications

A stand-alone microgrid has its own sources of electricity, supplemented with an energy storage system. They are used where power transmission and distribution from a major centralized energy source is too far and costly to operate. Additionally, they offer an option for rural electrification in remote areas and on smaller geographical islands.

## Benefits

The multiple dispersed generation sources and ability to isolate the microgrid from a larger network would provide highly reliable electric power.

## Search Results: Multi-agent System

Here's information about multi-agent systems from the search results:

### Definition
A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

### Capabilities
Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics
Agents in a multi-agent system are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling (or the system is effectively reduced to a monolithic system).

### Modern Developments
With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Applications
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

### Related Concept
A multi-agent system is not always the same as an agent-based model (ABM). The goal of an ABM is to search for explanatory insight into the collective behavior of agents obeying simple rules in natural systems, rather than in solving specific practical or engineering problems. The terminology of ABM tends to be used more often in science, and MAS in engineering and technology.

Links: [{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Distributed version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control"},{"title":"Category:Distributed version control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Distributed_version_control_systems"},{"title":"Distributed parameter system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_parameter_system"},{"title":"Talk:Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Decentralised system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralised_system"},{"title":"Hierarchical control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_control_system"},{"title":"Asynchronous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_system"},{"title":"Multi-room audio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-room_audio"},{"title":"Revision Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revision_Control_System"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about Distributed Control Systems:

## Overview

A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control.

## Key Advantages

The main benefit of DCS architecture is **reliability**. The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system. This mitigates a single processor failure. If a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process. Additionally, this distribution of computing power local to the field Input/Output (I/O) connection racks also ensures fast controller processing times by removing possible network and central processing delays.

## System Architecture

Level 0 contains the field devices such as flow and temperature sensors, and final control elements, such as control valves. Level 1 contains the industrialised Input/Output (I/O) modules, and their associated distributed electronic processors. Level 2 contains the supervisory computers, which collect information from processor nodes on the system, and provide the operator control screens. Level 3 is the production control level, which does not directly control the process, but is concerned with monitoring production and monitoring targets. Level 4 is the production scheduling level.

## Applications

DCS tends to be used on large continuous process plants where high reliability and security is important, and the control room is not necessarily geographically remote.

Here's an overview of autonomous vehicles based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car (AC), driverless car, robotic car or robo-car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.

## Classification Levels

The autonomy levels of vehicles are standardized by the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE):

- Level 1: Driver assistance, the vehicle controls steering or speed autonomously in specific circumstances.
- Level 2: Partial automation, the vehicle controls both steering and speed autonomously in specific circumstances.
- Level 3: Conditional automation, the vehicle controls both steering and speed under normal environmental conditions, but requires the driver to be ready to take control in other circumstances.
- Level 4: High automation, the vehicle travels autonomously under normal environmental conditions, not requiring driver oversight.
- Level 5: Full autonomy, where the vehicle can complete travel autonomously in any environmental conditions.

## How They Work

Autonomous vehicle software generally contains several different modules that work together to enable self-driving capabilities. The perception module ingests and processes data from various sensors, such cameras, LIDAR, RADAR, and ultrasonic SONAR, to create a comprehensive understanding of the vehicle's surroundings. The localization module uses 3D point cloud data, GPS, IMU, and mapping information to determine the vehicle's precise position, including its orientation, velocity, and angular rate. The planning module takes inputs from both perception and localization to compute actions to take, such as velocity and steering angle outputs.

## Current Deployments

Waymo operates commercial robotaxi services available to the public in Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Atlanta, and Austin.(no content)As of December 2025, it operates over 450,000 rides per week.

Links: [{"title":"Cruise (autonomous vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cruise_(autonomous_vehicle)"},{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"List of predictions for autonomous Tesla vehicles by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_predictions_for_autonomous_Tesla_vehicles_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicular_automation"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Autonomous racing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_racing"},{"title":"Waymo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waymo"},{"title":"Wayve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayve"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"}]

Here's an overview of autonomous vehicles based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car (AC), driverless car, robotic car or robo-car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.

## Classification Levels

The autonomy levels of vehicles are standardized by the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE):

- Level 1: Driver assistance, the vehicle controls steering or speed autonomously in specific circumstances.
- Level 2: Partial automation, the vehicle controls both steering and speed autonomously in specific circumstances.
- Level 3: Conditional automation, the vehicle controls both steering and speed under normal environmental conditions, but requires the driver to be ready to take control in other circumstances.
- Level 4: High automation, the vehicle travels autonomously under normal environmental conditions, not requiring driver oversight.
- Level 5: Full autonomy, where the vehicle can complete travel autonomously in any environmental conditions.

## How They Work

Autonomous vehicle software generally contains several different modules that work together to enable self-driving capabilities. The perception module ingests and processes data from various sensors, such cameras, LIDAR, RADAR, and ultrasonic SONAR, to create a comprehensive understanding of the vehicle's surroundings. The localization module uses 3D point cloud data, GPS, IMU, and mapping information to determine the vehicle's precise position, including its orientation, velocity, and angular rate. The planning module takes inputs from both perception and localization to compute actions to take, such as velocity and steering angle outputs.

## Current Deployments

Waymo operates commercial robotaxi services available to the public in Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Atlanta, and Austin.(no content)As of December 2025, it operates over 450,000 rides per week.

Links: [{"title":"Smart grid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_grid"},{"title":"Smart grid in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_grid_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Unified Smart Grid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unified_Smart_Grid"},{"title":"Smart Grid Energy Research Center - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_Grid_Energy_Research_Center"},{"title":"Smart Grid Interoperability Panel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_Grid_Interoperability_Panel"},{"title":"IEEE Smart Grid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_Smart_Grid"},{"title":"Smart grid policy of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_grid_policy_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Smart grids by country - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_grids_by_country"},{"title":"Open Smart Grid Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Smart_Grid_Protocol"},{"title":"Super grid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Grid"}]

I found comprehensive information about smart grids. Here's what you should know:

## Definition

The smart grid is an enhancement of the 20th century electrical grid, using two-way communications and distributed so-called intelligent devices.(no content)The term smart grid is most commonly defined as an electric grid that has been digitized to enable two way communication between producers and consumers.

## Key Functions and Benefits

Two-way flows of electricity and information could improve the delivery network.(no content)The potential benefits from a smart grid include increased reliability, more efficient electricity use, better economics, and improved sustainability.(no content)The improved flexibility of the smart grid permits greater penetration of highly variable renewable energy sources such as solar power and wind power.

## Components

Research is mainly focused on three systems of a smart grid – the infrastructure system, the management system, and the protection system.(no content)A smart grid includes a variety of operation and energy measures: Advanced metering infrastructure (of which smart meters are a generic name for any utility side device even if it is more capable e.g. a fiber optic router) Smart distribution boards and circuit breakers integrated with home control and demand response (behind the meter from a utility perspective) Load control switches and smart appliances, often financed by efficiency gains on municipal programs and Renewable energy resources, including the capacity to charge parked (electric vehicle) batteries or larger arrays of batteries recycled from these, or other energy storage.

## U.S. Policy and Development

Key federal legislation driving the development of smart grid-related technology for the American electrical system includes Title XIII of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 (EISA).

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Survey - This is a literature review article providing "an up-to-date overview of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control" that surveys existing techniques and applications.

**Key Entities Extracted (7 triples):**

1. **Distributed control system** - Core architecture concept for managing large networked systems
2. **Event-driven architecture** - Foundation for event-triggered communication scheduling
3. **Multi-agent system** - Framework for coordinating distributed networked agents
4. **Smart grid** - Application domain with communication constraints
5. **Intelligent transportation system** - Transportation coordination application
6. **Microgrid** - Localized electrical network application
7. **Self-driving car** - Automated vehicle coordination application

All entities are marked as "uses" (since this is a survey paper) and include proper Wikipedia URLs and relevance statements explaining their importance to the paper.

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The analysis is complete and the triples_output.json file has been properly formatted and validated.
